speaker: ANGIE
line: Oh gosh, go home Harold.

speaker: HAROLD
line: I'm not done yet.

speaker: ANGIE
line: Harold, you hear me? You should have gone home already.

speaker: HAROLD
line: I'm not done yet.

speaker: ANGIE
line: For praying out loud Harold, this ain't so difficult.

speaker: ANGIE
line: Harold, it's past your bedtime. It's ok. And the doctors will be worried about you. You did a good job today now you go home c'mon.

speaker: ANGIE
line: What the hell?

speaker: ANGIE
line: Jeez.

speaker: ANGIE
line: Oh God, oh my God! No! I'll get help! Oh!

speaker: ANGIE
line: Officer, officer!

speaker: OFFICER
line: Sir, this don't involve you.

speaker: ANGIE
line: There's a woman inside, she's bleeding, she's...

speaker: ANGIE
line: God. That's her! That's the girl I saw!

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Scully, take a look at this.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What am I looking at?

speaker: MULDER
line: The pin setter. You see the way it's wedged and broken?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yep.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mr. Pintero said the only way that would happen would be if considerable weight or pressure was placed on it from above.

speaker: SCULLY
line: This is where you saw the body?

speaker: ANGIE
line: Yes ma'am, she was caught up in the machinery. Her neck was cut.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And the blood from the victim was pooling where?

speaker: ANGIE
line: Right here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But both the body and the blood were gone when you returned?

speaker: ANGIE
line: Yeah, but like, like I said, the woman in the parking lot...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Was the same woman that you saw caught up here in the machinery?

speaker: ANGIE
line: That's right.

speaker: ANGIE
line: Look, I'm not making this up!

speaker: MULDER
line: No one's suggesting that you are, Mr. Pintero.

speaker: ANGIE
line: I saw the look on her face.

speaker: MULDER
line: Can I ask you a favor? Can I get a soda, a cola, something like that?

speaker: ANGIE
line: Sure.

speaker: MULDER
line: Thanks.

speaker: ANGIE
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: What is that look, Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I would have thought that after three years you'd know exactly what that look was.

speaker: MULDER
line: What, you don't believe in ghosts?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You're saying that what this man saw was the victim's ghost?

speaker: MULDER
line: Sounds more like a disembodied soul.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Which is just another name for a ghost.

speaker: MULDER
line: Except according to Mr. Pintero, this one was trying to communicate. It was speaking to him as if she was trying to tell him something. It sounds more like a death omen.

speaker: SCULLY
line: A death omen?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. It's a spirit being that arrives as a harbinger of death.

speaker: MULDER
line: This is the third reported sighting in as many weeks... and as many murders. Each time the victim appearing near the crime scene trying to communicate, trying to say something.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Communicate what?

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't know yet but, uh,...... thank you. If you hold on a second I may have an answer for you.

speaker: ANGIE
line: Hey! What are you doing?

speaker: MULDER
line: She is me.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What?

speaker: MULDER
line: Written onto the wax - she is me - look at this!

speaker: HUDAK
line: Three victims... all women... all approximately the same age, height, weight, hair and eye color... all attacked within the same six block area of each other. Our FBI profiling model suggests a white male, late twenties / early thirties. His victims were probably strangers to him... symbols representing other women in his life... perhaps all women. Hey you in the back! Are we boring you?

speaker: MULDER
line: No, not at all.

speaker: HUDAK
line: Because if you have nothing to contribute to this profile...

speaker: MULDER
line: No, actually I do have something to add. I think that following the FBI model in this case will not only fail to turn up the killer but will undoubtedly lead to more victims and more deaths.

speaker: HUDAK
line: You want to tell us who you are and what you base that on?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm Special Agent Mulder. This is Agent Scully. We're from the FBI. We're here following up a lead that seems to have been dropped - a statement made by the proprietor of the bowling alley that...

speaker: HUDAK
line: ... the guy that claims that he saw the victim...

speaker: MULDER
line: No, no, not the victim. Her apparition, what the Irish call a fetch, what is more commonly known as a wraith.

speaker: HUDAK
line: Oh, ok.

speaker: MULDER
line: Were there any written messages in any of these other cases?

speaker: HUDAK
line: Written messages?

speaker: MULDER
line: Do the words "she is me" have any meaning to you?

speaker: HUDAK
line: You mean Penny Timmons last words?

speaker: MULDER
line: Those were her dying words?

speaker: HUDAK
line: According to a 911 call we received...

speaker: MULDER
line: Well who made that call?

speaker: HUDAK
line: A nut.

speaker: MULDER
line: What do you mean?

speaker: HUDAK
line: There were no dying words. Penny Timmons larynx was severed. She couldn't cry for help even if there was help to cry for.

speaker: MULDER
line: And no one followed up on this lead?

speaker: HUDAK
line: No but, uh, I'll have someone get you the number and you can follow up on it.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'd appreciate that.

speaker: ALPERT
line: People! People! Listen up now. I've brought some folks who want to talk with you. Nurse Innes, could you gather the group?

speaker: INNES
line: All right everyone! Let's go, you know the drill. Get your seats. Group seating. Go on in. Harold, come on. Harold.

speaker: ALPERT
line: Good morning, everybody.

speaker: PATIENTS
line: Good morning, Mr. Alpert.

speaker: ALPERT
line: I've brought visitors today. They're investigating a crime. It's OK. They just want to ask you a few questions.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hi. I wanted to ask if anybody used the pay phone out in the hallway there on Friday night - because somebody called the police and reported a murder.

speaker: ALPERT
line: Sloppy Joe night.

speaker: MULDER
line: That was Sloppy Joe night. it, I did it. I'm just a human being, after all.

speaker: ALPERT
line: Chuck! Tell the truth.

speaker: CHUCK
line: No. I'm sorry, I didn't mean it. I... I lied. I lied but I'm just a human being.

speaker: ALPERT
line: Has anyone used the pay phone to call the police?

speaker: MULDER
line: Anybody recognize this woman?

speaker: CHUCK
line: That's the lady that got murdered.

speaker: VARIOUS PATIENTS
line: Yeah she's the one...I recognize her... I know her... She was murdered...

speaker: SCULLY
line: And, does anybody recognize this man?

speaker: VARIOUS PATIENTS
line: Oh, yes, yes, he did it... He did it... He's the murderer... He's a very funny man... He smiles a lot.

speaker: MULDER
line: The quiet man in the back.

speaker: ALPERT
line: Harold Spuller.

speaker: MULDER
line: The only one who didn't raise his hand, yeah. Has he ever been a problem?

speaker: ALPERT
line: Harold? No. He has a tendency to get a little worked up.

speaker: MULDER
line: Do you think I could talk to him.

speaker: ALPERT
line: Yeah, sure.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, I found something here Mulder... in these photos taken by the forensics team. The third victim, her left hand, that band of pale skin. It looks like she wore a ring on that hand.

speaker: MULDER
line: A wedding ring, yeah.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah. But she wasn't married.

speaker: MULDER
line: So what, he stole her ring?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, not at all.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, he switched it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And in all the other murders he repeated the same ritual, changing the ring on each of the victims.

speaker: MULDER
line: Nice catch, Scully. Any idea about the psychology at work?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, there's something called ego dystonia. It's a form of obsessive-compulsive disorder where a person has the persistent and inescapable impulses to change things, to organize, to reorganize. But it's not ordinarily something that escalates to a murderous impulse.

speaker: MULDER
line: Not ordinarily unless there was a more complex psychology at work, like pronounced mental illness.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You really think that the killer is a patient here?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm not sure if the killer is here, but certainly the person that made that phone call is, and I think his name is Harold Spuller.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Did he cop to making the call?

speaker: MULDER
line: No but he's about to.

speaker: HAROLD
line: I don't know anything. I didn't do anything. Leave me alone.

speaker: MULDER
line: You made that phone call, didn't you Harold?

speaker: HAROLD
line: No!

speaker: MULDER
line: Did you say the words "she is me"?

speaker: HAROLD
line: No!

speaker: MULDER
line: Have you ever heard those words?

speaker: HAROLD
line: No!

speaker: MULDER
line: Have you ever seen a ghost, Harold?

speaker: HAROLD
line: No! No! Please leave me alone.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well... when you're right, you're right.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Harold Spuller suffers from pervasive developmental disorder, which is sometimes called atypical autism. He's spent his entire life in and out of facilities just like this one. He has been medicated, he has received shock therapy and, aside from his other disabilites, he has been diagnosed with severe ego dystonic obsessive-compulsive disorder... which would explain the switching of the victims rings.

speaker: MULDER
line: So why all of a sudden?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You mean what made him snap? Why, I think his outburst clearly showed a frustrated impulse towards violence when he was put in a challenging situation.

speaker: MULDER
line: That outburst didn't come until after I'd asked him if he'd ever seen a ghost.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, the man is disturbed. You could see the pressure building in him from the moment the interview began.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why are you now so unconvinced that Harold Spuller is the man we came here looking for?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm sure Harold Spuller is the man that made that phone call. But what led us to him still remains unexplained.

speaker: SCULLY
line: "She is me."

speaker: MULDER
line: Uh huh, and the other apparitions, like the one Mr. Pintero saw at the bowling alley.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, I think I have an idea about that if not an explanation. Howard Spuller is at this facility voluntarily, which means he can come and go as he pleases, to kill those women or to hold down a job or both.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh Scully...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah. It's ok.

speaker: MULDER
line: You sure?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, it's just, um, I'm fine. I just need to find a washroom.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully?

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, you in there?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: They found another victim. A college student with her throat cut. Just about a half block from here.

speaker: MULDER
line: Her name was Loren Heller, age 21. She's single, apparently she was on her way home from a bar that she part-timed at after school. She had a ring on her left hand, switched to her right hand, pinky finger. She was dead less than an hour when she was found.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That would rule out Harold Spuller as the killer, huh?

speaker: MULDER
line: No, actually it doesn't. Harold's not at the home. He's nowhere to be found. His nurse locked him in his room after we left, but he managed to escape unnoticed.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't imagine he'd be too hard to find.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, but I think we should be the ones to find him, if only to find out what "she is me" means.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder... I...

speaker: MULDER
line: What?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I think I'm going to let you take care of that. I, uh, I think I'm gonna get this checked out just, you know, just to be safe.

speaker: MULDER
line: You want me to drive you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, no, I'm fine really. I've had the doctors keep a close watch and it's just, just precaution.

speaker: MULDER
line: You're sure?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm fine.

speaker: HAROLD
line: No... no... I just want to be left alone!

speaker: KOSSEFF
line: We've spoken about your fear. You've been afraid to express it to others, to Agent Mulder.

speaker: SCULLY
line: This is different.

speaker: KOSSEFF
line: How?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Several months ago, I was diagnosed with a cancerous mass - a nasal pharyngeal tumor that can not be operated on and, uh, cannot be treated by conventional medicine.

speaker: KOSSEFF
line: I'm sorry.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't mean for this to sound too dire. My health has been good. I have been checked up on a weekly basis.

speaker: KOSSEFF
line: You've kept working?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yes. It's been important to me.

speaker: KOSSEFF
line: Why?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why? Um...Agent Mulder has been concerned. He's been supportive through this time.

speaker: KOSSEFF
line: Do you feel that you owe it to him to continue working?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No. I guess I never realized how much I rely on him before this... his passion... he's been a great source of strength that I've drawn on.

speaker: KOSSEFF
line: What happened last night, Dana?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I saw something. I, I don't know what to trust. If I saw it because of the stress, because the image had been suggested to me or if it was a suggestion of my own fears.

speaker: KOSSEFF
line: Your fear of failing him?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Maybe.

speaker: KOSSEFF
line: What did you see?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I saw a woman who had recently been murdered. I saw her. It appeared as if she was trying to tell me something.

speaker: KOSSEFF
line: Do you know what?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No.

speaker: KOSSEFF
line: Are you sure?

speaker: ANGIE
line: Hey, you're back.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, I'm looking for Harold Spuller.

speaker: ANGIE
line: Harold? What for?

speaker: MULDER
line: Suspicion of murder.

speaker: ANGIE
line: You think Harold killed those women?

speaker: MULDER
line: You obviously don't think so, huh?

speaker: ANGIE
line: Harold's worked for me for 10 years. He might be crazy but he couldn't kill anyone. He's a sweet kid.

speaker: MULDER
line: You know where he is now?

speaker: ANGIE
line: He was here this morning when I arrived, arranging the shoes.

speaker: MULDER
line: He has a key?

speaker: ANGIE
line: No, he's got some damn way of getting in here through an abandoned building next door.

speaker: MULDER
line: Did you ever get lane 6 working?

speaker: ANGIE
line: No, not since I saw the girl.

speaker: MULDER
line: Harold? Harold? Harold, I just want to talk to you. Harold?

speaker: HAROLD
line: She is me... she is me... she is me... she is me... she is me... she is me...

speaker: MULDER
line: Harold?

speaker: HAROLD
line: She is me... she is me... she is me... she is me... she is me... she is me...

speaker: ATTORNEY
line: I want to make this clear from the start. My client is suffering from a mental disorder which impairs his judgement. He will not answer any questions regarding his guilt or innocence.

speaker: HUDAK
line: I'd be real happy if you'd quit talking right now.

speaker: ATTORNEY
line: Any time Harold becomes upset or unwilling to cooperate, this interrogation will end. Detective Hudak?

speaker: HUDAK
line: Tell me why you did it, Harold, huh? Come on, tell me why you killed those women.

speaker: ATTORNEY
line: What did I just say? This is totally unacceptable. I am prepared to tell my client not to cooperate.

speaker: MULDER
line: Harold? Harold, you knew those women who were murdered, didn't you? That's why you're scared. You're afraid they've come back to visit you. Penny Timmons.

speaker: MULDER
line: Missy Shapiro.

speaker: MULDER
line: Michelle Chamberlain.

speaker: MULDER
line: What was her shoe size?

speaker: HAROLD
line: Six and a half.

speaker: HUDAK
line: There you have it.

speaker: ATTORNEY
line: This is not a confession.

speaker: HUDAK
line: He killed them. He stalked them, he fixated on them, and he slit their pretty little throats. Isn't that right, Harold, huh?

speaker: ATTORNEY
line: Harold, as your paid attorney, I'm advising you not to respond to any more questions nor to cooperate with this investigation any further.

speaker: MULDER
line: Harold, there are people who think that you murdered these women. I'm not one of them. But I need your help for me to prove that. You think you can do that? I think you can.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mr. Pintero? I'd like to search the building for any ways in or out that Harold might have of the bowling alley.

speaker: ANGIE
line: Oh sure.

speaker: MULDER
line: Thanks.

speaker: ANGIE
line: You OK, Harold?

speaker: HAROLD
line: The shoes are out of order, Mr. Pintero. I'm sorry.

speaker: ANGIE
line: Hey. It's OK, buddy, don't you worry about it. You get this straightened out with these folks, then you'll come back and keep me in line.

speaker: HAROLD
line: OK, Mr. Pintero.

speaker: HUDAK
line: I want to know why the hell we're being led around like this.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm hoping it will become clear to us when we find it.

speaker: HUDAK
line: Is that right? He's going to show us something that's going to exonerate him?

speaker: MULDER
line: I think so.

speaker: HAROLD
line: Here.

speaker: HUDAK
line: Here what?

speaker: HUDAK
line: My God! They're all here, every victim.

speaker: ATTORNEY
line: This proves nothing.

speaker: HUDAK
line: He fixated on them.

speaker: ATTORNEY
line: I see hundreds of scorecards up here, thousands of names.

speaker: MULDER
line: Choose a name. Pick a name, pick any name up there.

speaker: HUDAK
line: Fred Graham.

speaker: MULDER
line: 200 game. that's not bad.

speaker: HUDAK
line: You're saying he has all these scores in his head?

speaker: MULDER
line: Including the victims.

speaker: ATTORNEY
line: You said this proves his innocence. How?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm not sure exactly, but I think that...

speaker: HAROLD
line: No! No!

speaker: HAROLD
line: No! No! No!

speaker: OFFICER
line: He just keeled... fell right over. I've done what I can. Must have been a heart attack.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey Scully. Is it too late?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No. What are you doing Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: I needed your help on something. I needed your medical expertise.

speaker: SCULLY
line: On what?

speaker: MULDER
line: Harold Spuller. Oh, I'm sorry, I didn't even ask you. What did your doctor say?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm fine.

speaker: MULDER
line: Good.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What's up, Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: Angie Pintero, the bowling alley guy? He's dead.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How?

speaker: MULDER
line: Natural causes. Congestive heart failure. Just keeled over right in the bowling alley.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That's what you need my medical opinion on?

speaker: MULDER
line: No. Howard Spuller had a preminatory vision of his boss's death.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't understand.

speaker: MULDER
line: Harold saw an apparation - what may have been Angie Pintero's disembodied soul at the moment of or just prior to his death.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How do you know?

speaker: MULDER
line: Because I was standing right there when he saw it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But you didn't see it yourself?

speaker: MULDER
line: No.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why?

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't have that facility, that kind of connection to the victims that would have made such a vision possible.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What's Harold Spuller's connection?

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't know its exact nature but I think it has something to do with his autism... that Harold experienced a profound attachment to these victims but because of his disability was unable to express the depth and power of those relationships, so somehow a psychic or preconscious bond was formed that went beyond the temporal.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh, wait a minute, so Harold knew the people that were killed?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, from the bowling alley, going back seven years.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Even if what you're saying is true, Harold wasn't the only one who claims to have seen these apparitions.

speaker: MULDER
line: No, but he does have something in common with those who've had the visions that is quite powerful in its own right.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Which is what?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, they were all dying... one of emphysema, one of cancer and now Angie Pintero.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Harold Spuller is dying too?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well that's what I need your medical opinion on.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, what if he isn't?

speaker: MULDER
line: I would be very surprised. What is a death omen if not a vision of our own mortality? And who among us would most likely be able to see the dead? Harold's at the resident home right now.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'll meet you there.

speaker: NEW HORIZON PSYCHIATRIC CENTER - 11
line: 42 PM

speaker: ALPERT
line: Well, you're back. Everything's going to be all right now, Harold. They just want us to keep you here for a little checkup. Nothing to worry about. Thanks, officers.

speaker: ALPERT
line: All right, Chuck. Go to bed. You can see Harold in the morning.

speaker: ALPERT
line: See. Everyone's so glad to see you back, Harold. You'll be able to talk to Chuck in the morning.

speaker: ALPERT
line: You still have to take your meds, Harold. Keeps you flying straight and level. Come on. It's the way we always do it.

speaker: ALPERT
line: Atta boy. Good stuff. Hi. We just brought him back.

speaker: INNES
line: Is he acting up?

speaker: ALPERT
line: No, I think he's just a little scared. I've been trying to get him to take his meds.

speaker: INNES
line: Why don't you let me sit with him for a bit.

speaker: ALPERT
line: OK, sure.

speaker: INNES
line: Take your poison, Harold. Go on. What you got to live for now, huh? What did you tell them, Harold? Did you tell them about your little girlfriends? Huh? Did you tell them how you were in love?

speaker: HAROLD
line: No!

speaker: INNES
line: Did you show them your pictures?

speaker: HAROLD
line: No!

speaker: INNES
line: What do you think those girls thought of you, Harold? Do you think they loved you back? No one could love you, Harold. Look at yourself. They looked at you and saw an ugly toad. A retard.

speaker: ALPERT
line: Agent Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: Thanks for accomodating us again.

speaker: ALPERT
line: Not a problem. We're all concerned for Harold.

speaker: MULDER
line: I understand.

speaker: ALPERT
line: You're bringing a doctor?

speaker: MULDER
line: Agent Scully's a doctor. If you can arrange to have Harold's medical records made available, that would expedite the...

speaker: ALPERT
line: Oh God. What's happened to you? Don't touch that. Don't touch that. It's just a cut.

speaker: MULDER
line: Tell me exactly what happened.

speaker: INNES
line: Like he just went wacko. I was trying to get him to take his meds and he went beserk. He jumps me, he starts pounding me like he wants to kill me.

speaker: MULDER
line: Did he say anything?

speaker: INNES
line: No, he just started screaming like a lunatic. Something's gone wrong with him. I think he's lost it for good. I'll be damned if I'm gonna to take care of him any more.

speaker: ALPERT
line: Look, I think you should get this cut on your head looked at.

speaker: INNES
line: Maybe, just give me a few minutes to get my nerves back.

speaker: ALPERT
line: OK everybody, everything's fine now. Come on, back to bed. That's right. Go on now. We'll see you in the morning. Night-night everybody. What can I do to help?

speaker: MULDER
line: I want you to call the police. Ask for Detective Hudak. Tell them what happened, tell them to look for Harold down at the bowling alley.

speaker: ALPERT
line: Are they going to arrest him?

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't see that there's any way around that. Sorry.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Maybe you were wrong.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, that's a superficial head wound, Scully. He didn't mean to kill her or maim her. That's not the work of a murderer if you ask me.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Then why would he do it?

speaker: MULDER
line: Maybe Harold is sicker than we thought he was.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Maybe. We won't know until we can examine him.

speaker: MULDER
line: I think there's someone you can talk to about it. Why don't you talk to his roommate and I'll see what I can do about finding Harold.

speaker: CHUCK
line: Oh hi.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Is your name Chuck?

speaker: CHUCK
line: Yes. Yes it is. Uh, Chuck Forsch. F-O-R-S-C-H. Chuck Forsch.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Do you, uh, do you share this room with Harold?

speaker: CHUCK
line: Yes, he's my friend.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Do you know where he is?

speaker: CHUCK
line: He's dying, isn't he? Harold is dying.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why do you say that?

speaker: CHUCK
line: Nurse Innes, she's, she's trying to poison him.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who told you that?

speaker: CHUCK
line: Harold. He said she told him she was putting poison in his meds.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Harold hasn't been taking his medication?

speaker: CHUCK
line: I don't know. I don't know everything, I'm only a human being. But I do know that Harold's my friend. He wouldn't hurt anybody. You know, he really loved them.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who?

speaker: CHUCK
line: Harold. He gave them to me. He was afraid.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Does anybody else know about these pictures, Chuck?

speaker: CHUCK
line: Nurse Innes.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How are you feeling?

speaker: INNES
line: I'm, you know, shaky.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Understandable.

speaker: INNES
line: Working with these people starts driving you crazy too. I'm just looking forward to going home.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Will your family be a comfort?

speaker: INNES
line: I live alone.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No children?

speaker: INNES
line: Just the one my husband ran off with.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Nurse Innes, I'm afraid I'm gonna to have to ask you to step out into the hallway.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Stay where you are! Drop it! Let it go!

speaker: SCULLY
line: She's alive. Let's get a paramedic in here.

speaker: ALPERT
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: You're cut.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, she attacked me. . You might want to bag that. I'm pretty sure it's the murder weapon.

speaker: SCULLY
line: She had been taking Harold's meds... clonazepam and clozapine... the unregulated effects of which are violence and unpredictable behaviour.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, but why did you even suspect her?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, I went in to talk to Harold's roommate and he said that Harold thought that she'd been poisoning him. So I went in to confront her and she just went off.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why do you think she killed those women?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't know. I mean, maybe in some drug-addled way, she was trying to kill happiness, Harold's happiness, his love for those women, maybe trying to destroy something she thought she'd never have again.

speaker: MULDER
line: She is me.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't know. Have they found Harold?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. They found in an alley a few blocks from here, face down on the pavement. They worked on him for twenty minutes but he couldn't be revived.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What happened?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, preliminary diagnosis is apnia - respiratory failure.

speaker: SCULLY
line: As a result of what?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, the paramedics are at a loss to explain that, but if what you're saying is true, that Harold stopped taking his medications, then that could have been a factor in his death - at least in the visions that he was seeing.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, Harold Spuller wasn't dying, Mulder. He, he was killed as a result of what that woman took away from him.

speaker: MULDER
line: Is that your medical opinion?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I saw something Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: What?

speaker: SCULLY
line: The fourth victim. I saw her in the bathroom before you came to tell me.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why didn't you tell me?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Because I didn't want to believe it. Because I don't want to believe it.

speaker: MULDER
line: Is that why you came down here, to prove that it wasn't true?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, I came down here because you asked me to.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why can't you be honest with me?

speaker: SCULLY
line: What do you want me to say? That you're right, that, that I believe it even if I don't. I mean, is that what you want?

speaker: MULDER
line: Is that what you think I want to hear?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No.

speaker: MULDER
line: You can believe what you want to believe, Scully, but you can't hide the truth from me because if you do, then you're working against me... and yourself. I know what you're afraid of. I'm afraid of the same thing.

speaker: SCULLY
line: The doctor said I was fine.

speaker: MULDER
line: I hope that's the truth.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm going home.
